image.altText: A close up photo of a phone with dating apps like Tinder, Grindr and Bumble on the screen.

items.synopsis: Popular online dating platforms are being threatened with greater government regulation unless they lift their standards and improve safety for users.

title.children: Dating apps threatened with regulation unless they improve safety

image.altText: Chris Bowen in a navy suit and tie in  front of the australian flag at a press conference

items.synopsis: The federal government releases figures to try to shut down growing calls from the opposition to consider nuclear as part of Australia's future energy mix, with Energy Minister Chris Bowen saying there would be a "massive cost to pay".

title.children: Energy Minister says replacing coal-fired power stations with nuclear would cost $387 billion

image.altText: A man in a suit is interviewed for television.

items.synopsis: One of the taxpayers helped by ATO whistleblower Richard Boyle has spoken out for the first time, describing the prosecution of the person who gave him a lifeline as "insanity". Mr Boyle's wife has also spoken to 7.30 about the toll the six-year-long ordeal has taken on the couple.

title.children: Richard Boyle faces the prospect of four decades in jail. His wife says all he did was tell the truth

image.altText: An open suitcase with a torch and bushfire guide inside; hands place will

items.synopsis: Most Australians are aware of the risk of natural disasters, not all of us actually prepare. But some are leading the way, having their suitcases packed with essentials, their properties cleared of fuel and learning how to fight fires.

title.children: 'Evacuate now': When Sarah got to the evacuation centre, she realised she'd forgotten to bring so much

image.altText: Voters at polling booths in Canberra in October 2016.

items.synopsis: It's the last day to register or change your details with the Electoral Commission if you want to vote in the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: Enrolment for the Voice referendum closes tonight. Here's what you need to know

image.altText: A profile picture of UK comedian Russell Brand

items.synopsis: Britain's BBC says it is "urgently looking into the issues" raised by allegations of sexual assault made against the broadcaster's former employee, British comedian and actor Russell Brand, who denies the accusations.

title.children: BBC investigating after sexual assault allegations made against Russell Brand

image.altText: A graphic with two young girls and a greyhound dog on the right with a book next to him.

items.synopsis: Reading to dogs at school is helping students improve their literacy and confidence — and giving some a reason to turn up.

title.children: Not all teachers walk on two legs. Meet the dogs changing outcomes in classrooms

image.altText: Three Wallabies players stand on the ground after the 2023 Rugby World Cup loss to Fiji.

items.synopsis: Never before have the Wallabies exited the Rugby World Cup at the pool stage, but the 22-15 result against Fiji has left Eddie Jones's squad in danger of missing the quarterfinals, writes Luke Pentony.

title.children: Wallabies' 'smash and grab campaign' on the brink of unravelling — and they only have themselves to blame

image.altText: One man wears a cap and blue check shirt and jeans smiling, another in denim jacket and shoulder length hair, smiling

items.synopsis: One of Australia's biggest rock bands, Silverchair ended with a whimper, not a bang. And so too did their friendships … almost.

title.children: 'We should have gone out in a blaze of glory': What really tore Silverchair apart

image.altText: Students in a classroom with male teacher in background.

items.synopsis: Poor mental health and excessive screen time are the biggest problems facing young people, according to a new survey of more than 2,000 Australian teachers. New resources will be made available for teachers in a hope to create more conversations on mental wellbeing.

title.children: 'Nervous rants' and crying at school: Teachers say poor mental health is the biggest issue facing Australia's youth

image.altText: Multiple neighbours characters look surprised

items.synopsis: Neighbours received an all-star send off in 2022 but now the beloved Australian soap is heading back to TV.

title.children: Neighbours returns to Australian screens tonight. Here's how to watch it and why it's back

image.altText: Business people walk past a shiny black sign that reads "Reserve Bank of Australia".

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is trading lower as investors wait for foreign central banks' next interest rates meetings, while Michele Bullock begins her first seven-year term as RBA governor. Follow live.

title.children: New dawn at the RBA as Michele Bullock begins as governor, ASX lower ahead of overseas interest rates meetings

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Oil price are pushing higher on Monday over concerns of a broader supply shortage as Saudi Arabia and Russia e xtended production cuts, while China is showing signs that its d emand for crude is recovering. Brent crude prices are up 0.3% to $US94.23 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate crude is around $US90.78 a barrel. "China's stimulus policy, resilient US economic data, and OPEC+'s ongoing output cuts are the bullish factors that support the oil market's upside movement," CMC Markets analyst Tina Teng said, referring to a reserve ratio cut by China's central bank last week to boost liquidity and support its economy. Brent and WTI have climbed for three consecutive weeks to touch their highest levels since November after Saudi Arabia and Russia extended supply cuts to the end of the year as part of the OPEC+ group's plans and as Chinese refineries ramped up output, driven by strong export margins. Both contracts are also on track for their biggest quarterly increase since Russia's invasion of Ukraine in the first quarter of 2022. "Production cuts, led by Saudi Arabia, stabilised the market in July but are now likely to push the market into a 2 million bpd (barrels per day) deficit in Q4 ," ANZ analysts said in a note. Global oil demand growth, on the other hand, is on track to hit 2.1 million bpd, they added, in line with forecasts from the International Energy Agency and the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC). "The subsequent drawdown in inventories in Q4 leaves the market exposed to further price spikes in 2024 ," ANZ said. — with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Oil prices edge up as concerns mount about future supply amid production cuts

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian sharemarket is continuing to trade lower on Monday, down 0.7% to 7,231 points as of 12:40pm AEST. (For live figures, head to the top of the blog and open up the pinned post.) All of the 11 sectors are in the red, with technology leading the falls, down 1.6%. Xero is down by 3.8%, and WiseTech Global has shed 2.5%. Energy is down 1.4%, and industrials and academic a nd educational services down 1.2% each. Health care has the smallest loss, only shedding 0.3%, with utilities, basic materials and real estate dipping by 0.4% each. The top five performers so far: Alumina +2.4% Paladin Energy +2.3% NRW Holdings +1.6% Perpetual +1.45 Bellevue Gold +1.3% The bottom five performers: Genesis Minerals -6.1% Weebit Nano -5.9% Washington H Soul Pattinson -5.5% PEXA Group -4% Credit Corp Group -3.9%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX continues to trade lower as tech and energy stocks lead losses

The top five performers so far:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If current losses hold, Aussie tech stocks could see their biggest fall since August 25, after dipping by 2.8% this morning. The fall in Australian tech stocks follows the losses on Wall Street on Friday, with the Nasdaq down 1.6% after chipmakers and megacap growth companies dropped. Software company Xero has fallen by as much as 4.1% so far, while WiseTech Global and Altium have slid by as much as 2.9% and 2.7% respectively. It's certainly one to keep an eye on throughout the day, that's for sure 👀
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian tech stocks on track for worst day in over three weeks

image.altText: For Rent sign

items.synopsis: The one-bedroom apartment was advertised as a delightful ground-floor apartment with its own private courtyard. Within a day the price was raised twice due to increased market interest.

title.children: It was advertised as a delightful ground-floor apartment. Within a day, the rental price had gone up twice

image.altText: A man holds a bike and a pair of sunglasses

items.synopsis: A cyclist who temporarily lost his sight after a magpie attack in northern Victoria is urging others to better protect themselves.

title.children: Surgeon rebuilds cyclist's eye after swooping magpie causes severe damage

image.altText: Wallabies players applaud Fijian players in a guard of honour after their Rugby World Cup match.

items.synopsis: The Wallabies' loss to Fiji for the first time in 69 years has left their Rugby World Cup hopes on a precipice, with penalties and ill discipline costing them dearly. But it could have been worse. Here are five quick hits from Fiji's momentous victory.

title.children: Five quick hits — Penalties, squad questions and a 'massively important' bonus point as Wallabies lose to Fiji

image.altText: A firefighter dousing a massive blaze in water, smoke, trees burning.

items.synopsis: Longer and complex fire seasons are placing increased pressure on rural fire brigades but a shortage of volunteers has raised concerns only a handful will be shouldering the load.

title.children: Fears lives could be lost due to lack of volunteer rural firefighters during 'traumatic fire season'

image.altText: The Voice to Parliament referendum booklet opened to the pages outlining how the Yes and No arguments will appear

items.synopsis: Unlike federal elections, a majority of Australian states will need to support the Voice to Parliament in order for the change to pass.

title.children: A double majority is needed for the Voice referendum to pass. What does that mean and how does it work?

image.altText: Two quinoa salad bowls with sweet potato, baby spinach, tinned tuna, pine nuts and red onion to illustrate our simple recipe.

items.synopsis: The average Australian diet barely scraped a pass on the healthy diet score card, with most adults eating too few veg and too much junk.

title.children: The CSIRO says we're eating too much junk and not enough veggies — here's how to improve your diet

image.altText: build-to-rent tenant Carly Hulls

items.synopsis: Build-to-rent developments are new to Australia but with long leases and freedom to have pets and make alterations they are being tipped as an answer to the rental crisis. But affordability remains a problem, writes Angelique Lu

title.children: Carly needed a stable rental home to raise her baby. A build-to-rent scheme was the answer

image.altText: Various private health fund cards

items.synopsis: The government spends billions of dollars a year subsidising private health insurance, particularly for those over 65. Could the money be better-used by investing directly in hospitals and primary care?

title.children: Who really benefits from private health insurance rebates? Not people who need cover the most

image.altText: A solemn Aboriginal woman stands next to a river amid dense vegetation. She wears red top, black cardie.

items.synopsis: Descendants of Aboriginal people who survived the Pinjarra massacre are undecided on how they will vote in the Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: Cheryl's people were massacred in this place. She hopes the Voice will further truth-telling and healing

image.altText: A long-haired man in a black wetsuit stands on the sand, holding a long yellow surfboard with a snake on the front of it.

items.synopsis: Authorities say the man had a permit to keep native animals, but did not have a permit to take the reptile out in public.

title.children: Pet python surfing session costs owner thousands after wildlife officers chase up viral footage

image.altText: A fighter jet flies throguh the air

items.synopsis: US military officials are appealing for the public's help to find an F-35 aircraft, which a pilot ejected from over South Carolina.

title.children: US military hunting for missing fighter jet after pilot ejects

image.altText: propeller airplane with REX logo sits on tarmac at dusk.

items.synopsis: Local governments own and operate hundreds of airports around the country, but many operate at a loss and rely on ratepayers to stay in the air. Councils say more funding is needed to support their community's "valuable asset".

title.children: 'Too crucial to fail': Why your local council is likely funding an airport that isn't profitable

image.altText: Woman holding open an empty pink wallet

items.synopsis: Family courts have never formerly acknowledged the financial impacts of abuse when dividing assets. But there are growing calls to better consider the devastating reality.

title.children: Calls to reform laws to stop DV survivors walking out with 'absolutely nothing'

image.altText: Ukraine

items.synopsis: Ukraine says it has recaptured Klishchiivka, an eastern village on the southern flank of Bakhmut, which fell into Russian hands during months of heavy fighting,

title.children: Zelenskyy praises soldiers for recapturing village near Bakhmut

image.altText: A woman's silhouette.

items.synopsis: Legal experts say a program that offers intermediaries to support people with a cognitive impairment, including mental illness or intellectual disability, during police interviews and court hearings is too limited and excludes many who would benefit from it.

title.children: After Claire experienced domestic violence, going to court was 'terrifying'. She says people like her need more support

image.altText: Rescuer in red hard hat stands before a mountain of crumpled  buildings

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

title.children: Libyan flood survivors face new water contamination risk, Gold Coast man fined for surfing with pet snake. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: Drew Barrymore with an upset expression recording a video.

items.synopsis: Drew Barrymore's initial decision to return to the air on Monday without her three union writers and with picketers outside her studio was met with criticism.

title.children: Drew Barrymore postpones return of daytime talk show until after Hollywood strikes

image.altText: A small parchment book with Arabic script

items.synopsis: Khaled Sabsabi was looking for exceptional stories in Muslim families' homes when he found a manuscript collection bigger than any owned by museums.

title.children: 'Mind-blowing' collections uncovered as artist looks to the suburbs for untold stories

image.altText: Man holds knife to staff behind counter of fast food restaurant.

items.synopsis: Crime-affected businesses in Queensland's north consider no longer accepting cash in a bid to protect their workers. But some worry the financial impacts could be crippling.

title.children: Small businesses weigh up the costs of going cashless after armed robberies, theft

image.altText: A composite photo of Wang Yi and Jake Sullivan.

items.synopsis: White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan meets with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi in Malta for 12 hours over two days, as the world's two largest economies seek to stabilise troubled relations.

title.children: US and Chinese representatives meet for 12 hours in Malta

image.altText: A girl wearing a navy blue school uniform in front of a brick school building.

items.synopsis: What teenagers in regional Victoria are thinking about the Voice and what it means for the future.

title.children: 'I'm excited to show my support': Young Victorians share their thoughts on the Voice to Parliament

image.altText: A numbat in the wild.

items.synopsis: Four juvenile numbats have been spotted at Secret Rocks for the first time, sparking new hope for the region's reintroduction program.

title.children: Fenced in from predators, these numbats are thrilling ecologists as they repopulate the Eyre Peninsula
